title: How did you build your first website? - Quora

response.answer_text: I honestly can’t remember many details about 1995, but I think I built my first site with Page Mill, an Adobe product. But I might have hand coded it with Mac’s textedit. My first page was a centered list of cool sites I found on the web and a heavily jpegged photo or two. It was published on space that AOL gave to its users. I’m not sure but I think AOL had its own FTP to upload it. I learned HTML the way we all did back then - by looking at someone else’s page, and copying it, filling in my own content, and making small changes, like the background color. There was no CSS to learn, so it was pretty easy. BGCOLOR=”#000000” is how you did it back in the day. And yea, we used uppercase for tags and attributes. My first professional site was for the small corporate communication firm I worked for. It was the definition of ‘brochureware’ in that I took our brochure and marked the copy up with some table tags and a swirly yellow sidebar. I uploaded it to a Network Solutions hosted server with Fetch, an FTP application I still use now and then. Netscape and the AOL browser were the browsers everyone used, although Internet Explorer changed things quickly. I still have an IE v. 2 Beta install disk (High density 1.44MB!).  I found it between a Using Netscape Navigator 2, with your Mac book and a Syquest disk. I really need to throw things out once in awhile. My first client site was the Institute for Clinical Social Work. It also was not much more than a brochure at the time. I probably used Page Mill for this too, although I switched to bbEdit fairly early. Page Mill didn’t really give you the features of multi-page search and replace or table tag creation that bbEdit had. I used bbEdit for about 15 years before switching to Sublime, then Atom. Mastering web design back then meant mastering nested HTML tables and PhotoShop (or Fireworks) to create optimized gif’s or jpg’s for typography. Our next client was for the Home Builder’s Association of Greater Chicago, and I started designing and building dozens and dozens of sites for home builders. All of them were brochures, and the only complicated feature was a contact form. JavaScript was only used for slideshows and a mortgage calculator, that I surely didn’t code all by myself. I tried Go Live and Dreamweaver, and might have finished a site or two with them. But I hated the messy code they produced. I had several years of desktop publishing experience by the time I started building sites professionally, so knowledge of layout, color, fonts, etc. certainly helped me learn web design. And yea, we called it web design, not development. It was design driven, not yet dominated by what tooling, library or framework you used. There were a smattering of web design reference sites to learn from, notably Web Monkey, from Wired. And the Bare Bones Guide to HTML which is still up. As far as books, Creating Killer Web Sites, by David Siegel, 1996 was a huge influence. Full of code and design tips, it introduced the concept of third generation web sites - sites driven by design, not code. It would be another 9 years before The Zen of CSS Design book came out and really changed how I built sites. CSS Zen Garden the site, came out in 2003, about the time I went freelance, but the book really helped explain how to implement design. My copy is falling apart. In 1999 I started blogging in a subdirectory of the company I worked for, and eventually moved it to kiplog.com. It went dormant in 2010. You can get a feel for what things were like by surfing the archive list at the bottom of this hand-coded, link-rotted page – KIPLOG - archive. Eventually I switched to a content management system called Movable Type, and a few years later to WordPress, moving me from static site development into full featured site development. If you enjoyed this long post by a grey beard talking about the old days, you might also like Paul McCann's answer to Are the golden years of web development over?

I did what most people do, I Googled it. Once I did that, I came across a bunch of resources, most of which was free to use. W3Schools Online Web TutorialsMozilla Developer NetworkThose are just a few options you can find online. Besides that, I also purchased enough books on everything from html, css, javascript, php, mysql, linux and everything in between. I studied like crazy and within a few months, I was able to code my very first and visually UNAPPEALING website. I was far from an overnight success when it comes to webdesign, I learn by making a bunch of mistakes and figuring out how to fix them. Today, I’m considered a Full Stack since I code using all the main aspects of a modern day web stack. I also use WordPress since it makes it very easy for my clients to take over once the work is done. The tools I used and use today. When I first started coding, I had my MacBook Pro and used Safari as the web browser, dreamweaver as the IDE and that’s about it. I got a shared hosting account and uploaded a completely html based website with some very basic css. Now I use more tools than I can mention in just one answer, mostly because I keep on switching various tools depending on my mood. I code on a Custom Built Windows PC, I also code on my MacBook Pro and on Various Distros of Linux.I use Firefox and Chrome as my browsers of choice.I use Atom Text Editor and Visual Studio Code for everyday use and on my larger projects, I use PHPStorm.I’ve come to favor using Task Runners like Gulp and Grunt to automate some of the lower level, time consuming tasks.Git is what I use for version control.That’s my short list of tools that I use to code a website. Now I have my own freelance webdesign company and I’m still learning new aspects of webdesign and development on a daily basis. Here’s a video I created a while back that goes over my journey to becoming a freelance web designer and developer.

BACKGROUND AOL was my first ISP in 1996. I dialed up with a 14.4 kbit/s modem. In 1996 I won 1st prize in an AOL Easter hunt contest. Among the amazing things I got, the most useful was a 28.8 kbit/s dial up modem, which made life so much better! 1997 I purchased a web building book with a CD in a bookstore. I used the AOL free web space to build three pages. One was for my astronomy club, our first site. The book included easy web building application that was like Word, which I was familiar with at the time. It made it easy to start to learn HTML. Then I would read the code in Notepad. It worked for me to use the code generator to make my pages and then work backwards to learn HTML as I went or as I needed to solve a page building problem. LOOKING BACK This was my learning method with previous technologies. I purchased or borrowed instructional books and code books and learned backwards. My favorite book which I still have is “The Fortran Coloring Book”. (It’s very funny!) The way those of us in the 1970’s learned programming was to check out code books and type code into our computers to make our own games. I typed in a Star Wars game, for example, on a mini “Interact” computer with a cassette based memory and only 8K to work with. HTML SELF TRAINING IN 1997 I learned how to place images (which I already knew now to make or edit with Windows Paint). I liked the table code. I dreamed of making an online store based upon this structure. At the very least my pages became ways to list my favorite pages for easy access by click, a type of home directory. I then became interested in directory based web design. That shaped my future web projects. My first web host based site was Speedyhunter[dot]com. (You can see early pages at The Wayback Machine.) I envisioned it as based upon the early Yahoo directory style. Today the concept works very well with current HTML. My other web based projects that I recall include a Babylon 5 fan page, a money finding site page (pay to read, coupons, etc.) and a type of my favorite sites page. SUMMARY You learn by doing it. Today you have what did not exist when I started making web pages. Before you started, people thought of making sites that help web designers select ASCII codes, colors, clip art, scripts, code directories and tutorials. Now we have sites that help you make web page backgrounds, interesting fonts. menus and much, much more. Plus you have template sites to help you learn HTML by getting those and looking at the code.

Original Question: How did you build your first website? I built my first website in 1996 with the free copy of Adobe PageMill which the CSUN student bookstore bundled with Adobe Illustrator 6.0. (A real bargain at $99, if I recall correctly.) Since this was the mid-90s, my first website had a splash page. It featured an animated GIF which I built with a free application called GifBuilder. The website was hosted on Earthlink, which offered free space to anyone with an Earthlink user account. (10 MB of space, if I recall correctly, and I didn’t come close to filling it.) I’m pretty sure I used Anarchie as my FTP client. I think I still have a copy of that site around here somethwere, but it’s probably on an iOmega Zip disk, which I haven’t had any way of reading for at least ten years. Ah well.

I taught myself HTML using the now obsolete A Beginner's Guide to HTML and coded my pages with SimpleText - Wikipedia. I also followed the alt.html FAQ: Frequently Asked Questions group on Usenet News. I don’t remember what FTP program I used. For awhile I was doing it from the command line (Unix), but I must have switched to something else at some point. Currently I use Transmit 5 for macOS. Now available. (I have version 4) I used the Lynx (web browser) until sometime after Mosaic (web browser) became available. I think I waited awhile before upgrading to a PPP account that allowed me to use Mosaic and then Netscape (web browser). My ISP provided users with Web space so I didn’t have to buy a separate hosting account until a few years later.

How I built my first website? With a lot of doubts. I used some HTML,CSS,Bootstrap and JavaScript. I had no idea what I wanted to do,but in the end I ended up creating a website about feminism.  This is only one of the pages. I don’t even knew I could do this. This was the first serious project I did.Hopefully I will do more in the future!

In 1995, I built an online web store for my e-wife’s brick and mortar lingerie store. I invented something I called a “shopping bag” using CGI scripts and then moved over to an apps engine called “W3Magic” to make it simpler for her to maintain. The pages were created on the fly from three text files containing the product descriptions. I had to keep the product images below 30 Kbytes because everyone used 28k phone modems back in the day. If you wanna see the website, its available on the Internet Wayback machine: Lingerie Outlet Don’t laugh, it was a very high tech for 1995…

Using microsoft Product called Front page. Using some of Basic HTML including MARQUEE tag which was cool that time. Photoshop designs and i don’t remember using any of CSS that time Front page was like Ms-word which was pretty easy and ended up Hosting it some where free like Free Web Hosting It was quite a days like first love and how it’s fucking serious job.

It was early spring of 1994, I had created basic web page for NCSA Mosaic browser. promptly decided not to touch these things until another year or so. In early 1995, with some book and Newly acquired Netscape Browser, and created more workable web page, and I think I created pretty basic page for it. But significant event was Netscape 3.0 in 1996, and by then far better documentation were available, and I created some more page, and created web site with some perl code for some indexing. And that site was actually on early internet for sometimes.

The story is quite interesting, it was the first time I did programming. One of my family members was working with websites so I asked him to give advice on how to start. He showed me basic syntax and how to upload to ftp server. I was blown away! So all night I have spent working on my website, learning about html, css ext. So my first website was a simple website with some random text. But my real website was also very simple but it was styled with css and added some basic jquery, I was very proud of it. :)

Using software I got from a computer magazine CD, using time during the school holidays: Netscape 3, Internet Explorer 3, Paint Shop Pro and Macromedia HomeSite for Windows 95. Ended up hosting it on Tripod. We’ve come a long way. I'm a senior front end engineer now.

I started building website using Wapka.Mobi! Started very badly but it got better gradually with the help of W3schools and some Google search and back then I only know how to work with Xhtml. I was able to build my first website with the help of a friend who is very good at HTML, she built the website while I follow along and I was able to create my first website. :D

I think it was Adobe Dreamweaver. It had quite a good UI at that time for building websites without knowledge of code. But as things didn't behave as expected I started to inspect things (HTML) happening in the back and it just exploded after that :) But those were my beginnings.

I have just created a website for me and I just used the help of motocms website builder for this purpose. It is a very cool and easy in use tool which you can try out too. I am sure you will find it helpful and nice for your needs too
